moves.1. e4: My opponent had white pieces and started with e4.
moves.1... e6 2. d4 d5: After e6, d4, d5 we have french defence.
moves.3. Bd3: The variation played by white is called the Schlechter variation.
moves.3... Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7: After Nf6, e5, Nfd7 was play, this position reminds me of Steinitz variation, but instead the knight on c3, white has the bishop on d3
moves.5. Qg4: Qg4, At the first glance, I thought this move is weird, why would white develop the queen so early in the opening? (I'm not sure if this is the main line) then I had a good look, realized that this move is not bad, because it stops me from developing my dsb, the queen also is now defending d4 and I can't really chase her away successfully, h5 would weaken my kingside.
moves.5... c5: C5, I decided to play solid opening, this is the most reasonable move in the position, attacking white center immediately, with the intention to play Nc6 or Qb6 next.
moves.6. c3: C3 maintains the pawn chain, which is the best move.
moves.6... Nc6: Nc6 adding more pressure to white's center.
moves.7. Ne2: Ne2 was play, this allows white to play f4 in the future, also that his queen would not be short on squares.
moves.7... cxd4 8. cxd4 Nb4: After the tension between the pawns was resolved Nb4 was played, trying to trade off white's lsb.
moves.9. Qg3: Qg3, the bishop has no place to go, so it has to be protected.
moves.9... Nxd3+: Nxd3+, finally I got rid of the pesky bishop, which was aiming at my king side.
moves.10. Qxd3 Bb4+: Bb4+ The queen is no longer attacking g7, this allows me to develop my bishop with check.
moves.11. Nbc3 O-O: Simply castling king side, safety first.
moves.12... f6: f6 undermines white's center with the idea to open up f file.
moves.13... fxe5 14. fxe5: F file is now opened up, white can not castle king side.
moves.14... Nb6: Nb6, the knight was not doing anything on d7, now it's going to c4, which would be an excellent square.
moves.15. a3 Bxc3: I had a proper look at Be7, but I didn't like it, because white would gain initiative, so I took the knight.
moves.16. Bxc3: I think Nxc3 would be better, because after this move, white's bishop is now blocked by his own pawn.
moves.16... Qg5: I found this good move, Qg5, not only attacks the g2 pawn, but also stops white from castling queen side.
moves.17. Ng3: White protects the g2 pawn with Ng3, maybe Qg3 could be played try to trade queens. His king is now exposed in the center.
moves.17... Bd7: Bd7, trying to get the lsb involved.
moves.18. Bd2: Bd2 was played, attacking the queen and gaining some initiative.
moves.18... Qh4: my queen would be useless on e7 or d8, so Qh4 was played, keeping the queen active.
moves.19. Be3: Not sure why this move was played, surely castle queen side would be better, this move invites me to play Nc4
moves.19... Nc4: Nc4 forking the bishop and the b pawn.
moves.20. Bf2: Bf2 preserves the bishop, maybe planning to play some discovered attack on my queen.
moves.20... Qf4: I think Nxb2 would be better, but I wanted to protect my queen first.
moves.21... Rf7: Planning to double the rooks on f file.
moves.22. b3: B3 attacks my knight. Nb6 would throw my knight out of the game, so I have to find a move better than Nb6.
moves.22... Qd2: Qd2 was play, if white trades queens in this position after Nxd2 white would be in trouble.
moves.23... Na5: Na5 provokes white to play b4.
moves.24. Ra2: Ra2 reasonable move, chasing my queen away.
moves.24... Qg5 25. Re2 Bb5: Bb5 skewers the rooks, but I overlooked Be3.
moves.26. Be3 Rxf1+: Rxf1+ was played first, I was hoping white to recapture with his queen, if that happens, I would play Qg6 moving the queen out of the harm's way first and then capture the rook on e2.
moves.27... Qe7: Qe7 was played, attacking white's a pawn.
moves.28. Ra2 Rf8: Rf8 reoccupies the open file and adding pressure to the knight.
moves.29. Nd2: Nd2, getting out of the attack and protecting f1 square.
moves.29... Qh4: I noticed that white's back rank is weak, so I played Qh4, if white moved his queen away from defending his back rank, Qe1 check would be troublesome for black.
moves.30. a4 Ba6: I played Ba6 then immediately regretted playing it.
moves.31. b4: yes because of this move, I thought I was in trouble and would lose a piece.
moves.31... Bc4: I played Bc4, well at least I can get a rook for knight and bishop, but then I remembered that white still have the back rank problem, after bxa5, Bxa2, the queen can't recapture, because Qe1+ would be devastating.
moves.32. Rc2: white saw that and played Rc2, which is not an accurate move.
moves.32... Bd3: This move pins the rook to the queen.
moves.33. bxa5 Bxc2: Queen still can't recapture due to the same problem.
moves.34. Qb5: Qb5, this move was actually a blunder, but ironically I responded with a blunder move (Bxa4), I should have played Qe1+ check straight away, I thought after Qe1+ white can play Nf1, but I overlooked the move a6, which would be winning for me.
moves.34... Bxa4: Bxa4 same threat, if queen takes bishop then Qe1+
moves.36... b5: I could not allow this pawn exchange, so b5 was played, supporting the bishop
moves.37. Qg4: White would obviously play Bh6 next, also white's queen is attacking my e6 pawn.
moves.37... Qc8: I played this sneaky move, protecting e6 while aiming for Qc1+, if white plays Bh6 next, it would be game over for him.
moves.38. Bh6: And it happened, he forgot about his back rank completely, h3 should have been played...
moves.38... Qc1+: Qc1+ The knockout punch... There is no way out for white in this position. GG

gameName: Sir, you've forgot your back rank
